slidelink.displaytext: Data Analytical Thinking and Methods (Total Session Length: 42:46)
Applied Example: How Research Funding Shapes Science (4:20)
Privacy, Big Data, and the Public Good (0:25)
Approaches to Protect Information About Individuals (0:40)

search.slidetext: data analytical thinking and methods julia lane funded by a grant from the www.thegovlab.org

economist professor in the wagner school of public policy at new york university provostial fellow in innovation analytics and a professor in the center for urban science and policy u.s. census bureau federal statistical system julia lane

measures measures everywhere we have to stop and think (with apologies to samuel taylor coleridge) what are we measuring? how are we measuring it? why are we measuring it? what are we missing? how can we draw inference? are we protecting human subjects? can entities be reidentified? key ideas

session outline define a research question (what are we measuring?) define a research question (what are we measuring?) think about what data are available and the measurement error (how are we measuring it?) link datasets (what are we missing?) statistical approaches (how can we draw inference?) address privacy and confidentiality/ethics (are we protecting human subjects?) disseminate results (can people be reidentified?)
define a research question

here’s the problem “big data” is an imprecise description of a rich and complicated set of characteristics, practices, techniques, ethics, and outcomes all associated with data. (aapor) there’s no single definition of big data by characteristics: volume, velocity, variety (and variability and veracity) by source: found vs. made by use: professionals vs. citizen science by reach: datafication by paradigm: fourth paradigm observational science scientist gathers data by direct observation scientist analyzes data analytical science scientist builds analytical model makes predictions computational science simulate analytical model validate model and makes predictions data exploration science data-driven science: data captured by instruments or from the web, or data generated by simulation information extraction processed by software placed in a database/ files scientist(s)/ scholar(s) analyze(s) database/files access crucial source: lee giles jim gray’s paradigm

define a research question write down a conceptual framework/hypothesis check the literature develop an empirical approach view “spurious correlations” view “spurious correlations” view “spurious correlations” view “spurious correlations” view “spurious correlations” view “spurious correlations” research funding economic & social outcomes step 1 step 2 step 3 for example: source: http://www.tylervigen.com/spurious-correlations

motivating policy question the challenge completing budgetary priorities in the u.s. and in many other countries there has much more focus on making investments in research and the goal is: to increase economic competitiveness increase innovation promote high wage jobs if you are going to make an argument about reallocation of resources from one area into another: what’s the storyline going to be? what evidence will you provide?

defining a conceptual framework how does funding stimulate economic and scientific activity? reflection question not necessarily true a big data problem measure funding capture the inputs into the production function trace the outputs
data availability and measurement errors

applied example: how research funding shapes science example problem: how research funding shapes scientific outcomes research funding scientific outcomes: products publications research questions: what gets funded? who gets funded? what gets purchased? how are purchases used? many problems: data not in one place (across government agencies) need to “scrape” data from web text analysis techniques to analyze “unstructured” data identify names of people who get funding examples of workflows, data sets, and data points needed to investigate how research funding shapes science

building a large-scale researcher databaseemerging problem: none of the records are centralized scientific outputs and biographic publications(pubmed;citeseer) author nameskeywords, abstracts citations author namespublications citationsaffiliations oclc’s world cat,proquestdissertationsadvisors inputs grants (nih, nsf)pi names star metrics investigator and trainee names occupations other outcomes census datacensus variablesemploymenthistory (ui records) employer sed/sdrdoctoral student data umetricslarge-scale, disambiguated, longitudinal researcher data web searchescv data uspto patent datainvestor namestechnology classes how can we find out what researchers do?

measurement error total error = row error + column error + cell error (thanks to paul biemer, 2015) what am i measuring from the data i have compiled? have i got it right? reflection question reflection question target population sample survey question design missing data? total survey error measurement framework reflection question what are the sources of error from the data generating process that we are looking at with big data? up next

row error omissions example: some rows are missing, which implies that elements in the target population are not represented on the file. duplications example: some population elements occupy more than one row erroneous inclusions example: some rows contain elements or entities that are not part of the target population

column error specification error am i capturing the right set of variables? concept what is the underlying latent variable of interest? measurement what is the actual measurement used? interpretation how is the analyst interpreting it?

cell error content error example: problems in the measurement process, transcription error, data processing error. specification error example: error in data capture for specific units. missing data example: the measurement process, transcription error, data processing error.

consequences for inference source: paul biemer, 2015 regression on y on x with and without measurement error in x the figure on the left is the population regression with no measurement error in the x variable. on the right, measurement error was added to the x-values with a reliability ratio of 0.73. note its attenuated slope which is very near the theoretical value of 0.77. drawing inference say something about the relationship between variable x and variable y make sure that’s not spurious example
link datasets

linking datasets the old way of matching: step 1 take two lists. step 2 measure similarity between objects in the list. step 3 if similarity between objects is high, call the two objects a match. problem: hard to know what similarity metric to use, and what threshold should count as a match. new way of matching (via machine learning): step 1 take two lists that are matched by hand (i.e., a labeled “training set”). step 2 use a machine learning algorithm on training data to obtain a probabilistic model of matching. step 3 use the fitted model on new, unlabeled data to estimate new matches. benefits: matching threshold and similarity functions informed by human expertise, and learned directly from data.
statistical approaches

statistical issues what is the latent variable of interest? reflection question what might my measures be? startups young firms high growth firms latent variable of interest: economic innovation reflection question reflection question what is the counterfactual? what are my confounding variables? what could also explain the desired outcome? how to think about inference? frequentist parameters are fixed data is repeatable random sample bayesian data is fixed parameters are unknown and described probabilistically
address privacy and confidentiality/ethics
when you have big data, it’s impossible to ask for consent barocas and nissenbaum 2014 issues of consent
disseminate and replicate results
protecting confidentiality
what is disclosure? identity disclosure linkage with external available data attribute disclosure inferential disclosure taxi cab data revealed: where people lived where they worked
approaches to protect information about individuals basic risk measurement recoding local suppression pram (postrandomization) information loss measures shuffling microaggregation adding noise
example of effect burkhauser, richard v.; feng, shuaizhang; jenkins, stephen p.; larrimore, jeff the journal of economic inequality 9.3 (2011): 393-415.

and a reminder of “why” measures measures everywhere – we have to stop and think: what are we measuring? how are we measuring it? what are we missing? how can we draw inference? are we protecting human subjects? can people be reidentified?
